item.title: Defining Music Services: Artist-facing vs. Listener-facing
item.description: Introduction When people think of music services they often think of streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music, and the like. While these are the largest players in the music services industry, streaming is far from the only service provided in the music industry. Music services can largely be split into two categories: listener-facing and artist-facing services. Listener-facing services are those which are geared towards helping listeners find new music (music discovery), save and store music they like, and listen to music by streaming remotely (Spotify) or playing from local storage (iTunes).

item.title: Problems in the Music Industry: The Need for Better Recommenders and Improved Music Discovery
item.description: Artist Compensation and Counting Streams Firstly, the current model for compensating artists (adopted by Spotify and Apple Music, the two largest music streaming service providers) is entirely dependent on the number of streams an artist can generate. Therefore, in the interest of making more of their product, artists have started to put out albums with high numbers of individual tracks. “Releases by Migos (Culture II, 24 tracks), Rae Sremmurd (SR3MM, 27 tracks), and Drake (Views, 20 tracks; More Life, 22; Scorpion, 25) don’t encourage being heard in full on one sitting, in fact, they actively discourage repeat listens.
